title: VIRGIN DAISIES - font ID - sans/serif hybrid
content:
Looking for an ID on the font used (or based from) this logo for Virgin Daisies.

Many thanks in advance,  
Danny

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215im_/http:/typophile.com/files/vd_port01_4239.jpg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [vd\_port01.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/typophile.com/files/vd_port01.jpg) | 23.42 KB |
author: Danny_Miller

comments.content:
No luck in finding a match, but I know who designed the identity:  
 [http://www.wideandnarrow.co.th/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.wideandnarrow.co.th/ "http://www.wideandnarrow.co.th/")

Wasn't able to spot a match either, probably a customization of an existing typeface.  
Some client for customization: [Seconda](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/seconda) Round, Soft and XtraSoft, [Accent Graphic](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/g-type/accent-graphic), [Minerva](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/minerva), [Carisma](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/castletype/carisma), [Euro Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/profonts/euro-sans-pro), [Bodoni Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/bodoni+sans), [Seaside](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/andrijtype/seaside) (probably the closest), [Contax Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20150328193215/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typeinnovations/contax-sans/)
thanks so much for the helpful suggestions Ryuk!
I’m intrigued by the sample’s demi-serifs, but didn’t find anything similar with the requisite stroke contrast and serifs....

You're right Kevin that's probably why I assumed from the beginning it could have been started from a Sans (and not a Serif). 'Virgin Daisies' and 'Wide & Narrow' are from Thailand, maybe the customization was based on the latin counter-part of some font for the Thai language...
